ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: So much! I learned all about coding, python, working with google collab notebook, and so many different methods regarding digital humanities.
Coding skills in python, general data science/ digital humanities literacy, and how to critically ask and answer question through computational analysis.
Data science methods for digital humanities, data visualization, Python
I learned how to effectively visualise different forms of data and data mine.

I learned so much about a variety of data mining and visualization techniques, from named entity recognition to topic modeling and color extraction. This course also had easily the best introduction to Python and using APIs I've ever had (and I'm a CS major).

This course gives an overview of coding in python, but importantly goes beyond the stats/pandas work in other YData courses and teaches more project-oriented tools. Some of the topics on the syllabus looked intimidating but Cathy and Doug are extremely good at explaining difficult methods in lay-persons terms. They made everything approachable!

Basic Python coding skills and data visualization in Tableau. Computational methods in text and image analysis, including: clustering & classification, topic modeling, word embeddings, color extraction, and visual similarity. How to create your own digital humanities project, including selecting, analyzing, and visualizing data in pursuit of a historically-inflected argument.

You learn so much in this course about digital humanities and new possibilities for computer science. We learned about AI, distant reading, color extraction, and many more techniques to analyze humanities data

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Truly all strengths  it was an absolutely incredible course! It was a pleasure being taught by Doug and Cathy  I learned so much that I feel I will actually retain.
The strengths of this class are the two professors -- Doug and Catherine. They are both absolutely amazing and were responsible for making the course so rewarding.
This course was genuinely incredible.

This was one of the best courses I've taken at Yale. Perfectly organized, not very challenging and I still learned about so much incredibly useful tools. Doug and Catherine were great lecturers and highly knowledgable about their field.

The lecturers, Cathy and Doug, are phenomenal. I am so grateful that I took this course because they made programming approachable in a way that no other programming course I have tried has been. I have absolutely zero recommendations for how the course could be improved. It was the best course of my whole degree. Looking at my final project, I feel like I learned so much and improved my knowledge of programming a lot. But, importantly, it was never painful and I was always excited for class.

Cathy and Doug are both phenomenal human beings and wonderfully clear instructors. If you have never coded before or only have basic experience, their labs give the clearest introductions to Python that I have ever seen. I wish I'd been able to take a class like this / learn from someone like Doug when I was just starting out. As for the course itself, the lectures are really interactive and Cathy is so supportive in helping you design your own project and find a dataset that suits your interests and needs. I can't think of any real weaknesses! If anything, the psets could have been slightly more difficult; unlike other computer science courses I've taken, I didn't spend very much time actually learning and understanding what each line of code was doing, because the psets were modeled after labs and graded on completion. However, I appreciate the need to accommodate the wide breadth of coding levels present in this introductory class. I don't know if I'm naming weaknesses so much as wishing there was an intermediate or advanced version of this seminar, so we could keep going!

The format was perfect. One day would be devoted to learning about a technique and the next we would all work on how to use it using google collab. I am not comfortable with coding but the instructions were really easy to follow.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The virtual labs were great!
Everything succeeded, instructors immediately acted upon class feedback to make the course as enjoyable and effective as possible.
The live coding format with the Google Colabs was great and worked very naturally in a virtual format.
Response to mid-semester student feedback about breakout rooms was great!
The lecture and lab format worked really well.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: ABSOLUTELY! Please do yourself a favor and take this course, especially if you're interested in the humanities. I had no prior experience with code at all or working with data, and I loved everything about this course.

Yes, Doug and Cathy are those rare teachers who are truly invested in their students learning and mental health. They continuously took the time to meet outside of class / scheduled office hour times to talk through concepts or students projects. Their enthusiasm for digital humanities is contagious!
YES! I would absolutely recommend this course to any student, regardless of their level of experience with coding. The professors made the class accessible to anyone.
Yes, I recommend this course to anyone interested in data science. Its the best data science course Ive taken at Yale.

This is easily one of the best courses I've taken at Yale. If the subject interests you, you should definitely go for it. The lecturers are fantastic, the workload is very low and the course is perfectly organized. You also end up learning a lot of incredibly useful coding and data visualization techniques, and then get to put them to use on a final project of your choice. As a CS major, I can also say that this course had a better introduction to Python and APIs than any other class I've taken - Doug is an absolute treasure.
This was the best course and I have already told half of Yale College to try to get into it next spring. I cannot say enough good things about it. I have never reviewed a course so highly before.
Absolutely! Instructors were some of the best I've had at Yale. Unbelievably amazing explanations of concepts + genuine care for students. These two professors are gems!

Yes, absolutely! Take this course! It is so fun and you gain really practical computational skills to pursue humanities research questions that interest you. If you've never coded before, it will be perfect for you; even if you have experience, Cathy and Doug are amazingly accommodating and there to push you and direct you as needed.
Yes, we discussed so many things that I never knew were even possible! It really expanded my understanding of computer science and tech within humanities.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live virtual lectures on Tuesdays, live virtual lab on Thursday.
virtual seminar over Zoom
Live virtual lectures and live virtual coding labs
